column4: and some units need -3 depending on age #irnd

text: One last thing - you should be white balancing most cameras ANYWAY because they all vary significantly unit to unit #irnd
@MikeTonge yes sometimes but time consuming as has to be shot under neutral light (as often we‚Äôll add colour for creative effect etc)
So surprised by number of top colourists recently telling me how much time they spend fixing IRND issues. Rant over. #irnd
You need to fix this shit early before it‚Äôs too far from the sensor data. Or buy Formatt Firecrests which have nearly no colour bias #irnd
I think people are feeling some sort of ‚Äúkeep it clean in camera‚Äù thing that‚Äôs stopping them running a white balance. #irnd
Then that info can just be offset to your ‚Äòcreative‚Äô white balance by the AC when adding a new filter #irnd
‚Ä¶ or in prep
column4: test each filter and figure out the required offset in kelvin and +/- green under both daylight and tungsten conditions #irnd

text: So either do a simple white balance under a known temperature of light when changing to a new filter‚Ä¶ #irnd
Plus your DIT/colourist will spend a HUGE amount of expensive time fixing something that is trivial to sort before pressing record #irnd
It‚Äôs not just a case of clicking an eyedropper on something white. It‚Äôs a complex transform that‚Äôs going to produce artefacts. #irnd
Correcting the green/warm bias from these filters in the grade is

text: You want to get that colour bias sorted as early as possible in the image chain. Definitely before it‚Äôs compressed to ProRes

text: It seems a lot of DPs are leaving that to the DIT or the colourist to remove. That‚Äôs a really bad idea. #irnd
